text: I know I probably go on and on and on
about this but I'm a huge fan of all
kinds of ethnic cuisines and I'm really
lucky cuz I live in a really diverse
neighborhood where I can go out and eat
whatever kind of food whenever I want
but I also like to cook it at home and
I'd like to adapt the recipes for my
friends and family and for all of you
guys to cook in your homes so what I try
to do is pair things down to their
essence figure out what really needs to
be there what doesn't and then make
recipes using those ingredients today
I'm making a 10 Dory chicken and I think
it's got all the great flavors of the
classic and it's super easy
start off by mincing or chopping half of
an onion so you can just throw your
onion right into your blender the base
flavors for this ten Dory are your onion
ginger and garlic which is the basis for
many many curries so I have two cloves
of garlic crush give it a coarse chop
not really important again if it's too
fine because everything is gonna be
blended up a piece of ginger same thing
you can just chop that up a little bit
about an inch so if you use these three
ingredients in combination the onion
ginger and garlic you're starting off
with a curry kind of flavor right off
the bat but to make it even more
delicious and more aromatic you're gonna
add some spices add a half a teaspoon of
ground cumin and a half a teaspoon of
ground coriander and then of course
yogurt cuz yogurt is the base for Ted
Dori I don't know if you knew that maybe
you didn't one cup of low-fat yogurt
this adds tanging is it tenderizes your
chicken a little bit and some lemon
juice a tablespoon lemon juice and then
a tablespoon of vegetable oil blend it
up now this tandoori is not gonna have
that electric color they use
because well it doesn't have food
coloring in it which is where most of
that coloring really comes from I think
sometimes maybe some recipes might have
had saffron or something else that gave
it a natural orangey color but I think
that most of the time tandoori really
just has food coloring in it and I'm not
a huge fan of that are you this marinade
makes enough for a whole chicken about
four and a half pounds this one is cut
up into quarters you want to get this in
the refrigerator and marinate it for at
least four hours and up to overnight I
can tell it's gonna be good already have
a rimmed baking sheet lined with foil
and then a wire rack if you have one
that helps air circulate around your
chicken which makes for even golden
defying yes I just made up a word
so what remove your chicken from the
marinade let the excess drip off and
then just put it on to your rack have
your oven preheating to 500 degrees you
want to cook this until it's charred in
spots that'll take about 35 minutes at
500 you're gonna want to turn it once or
twice and then you reduce the oven
temperature to 450 degrees and cook it
until the chicken is completely cooked
through as easy is that beautiful huh I
can't even tell you how fragrant it
smells in here when this was cooking it
was amazing the great thing about having
that aluminum foil in the bottom of that
pan is that it's really easy cleanup I
like to serve this with a little bit of
lemon because there was lemon in the
marinade so I add a couple wedges of
lemon to the platter right before
serving so people can squeeze more on
top
plus it makes it look pretty
and then why not a little bit of
cilantro I think that would be nice too
it's just nice to have a little bit of
something fresh on there if you have it
on hand and just like that you have
fantastic tandoori chicken at home
hi guys thanks for watching this video
be sure to click here if you want to
subscribe and click over here if you
want to continue watching more great
videos like this
